summary: This document is an email chain from October 2, 2019, forwarding a private letter addressed to Attorney General William Barr. The letter, from Conchita Sarnoff, questions the legal classification of a victim's case as child sex trafficking under the TVPA, based on the victim's own testimony describing voluntary actions and lack of force, fraud, or coercion. It suggests a need for legal clarification on the definition of child sex trafficking.

persons.name: Conchita Sarnoff
persons.role: Author of letter to Attorney General
persons.context: Writes a private letter to AG William Barr analyzing a victim's testimony in the Epstein case and questioning its classification as child sex trafficking under the law.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Addressee of a private letter from Conchita Sarnoff discussing the legal parameters of a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the case; the letter references a victim's testimony describing sexual activities with him and Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein in the victim's testimony regarding sexual activities and travel arrangements.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Named as one of the attorneys who conducted a telephone interview with the victim, the record of which was filed in 2011.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Named as one of the attorneys who conducted a telephone interview with the victim, the record of which was filed in 2011.

connections.description: Sarnoff sends a private, confidential letter directly to Attorney General Barr offering legal analysis of a victim's case.
Described together in the victim's testimony as directing her travel and engaging in sexual activities with her.
The victim (Jane Doe 102) testified to engaging in sexual activities with Epstein beginning at age 15.
The victim's testimony includes sexual activities with Maxwell.
Both are attorneys who conducted a joint telephone interview with the victim.

events.title: Filing of Jane Doe 102 vs. Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: First complaint filed by Jane Doe 102 against Jeffrey Epstein in the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Victim's Telephone Interview Filed
events.description: Record of a telephone interview with the victim conducted by attorneys Jack Scarola and Brad Edwards was filed.

events.title: Email Forwarding Letter to AG Barr
events.description: An email is forwarded within the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, containing Conchita Sarnoff's private letter to Attorney General William Barr.

keyFacts: A letter to AG Barr argues a victim's testimony does not meet the legal criteria for sex trafficking under the TVPA, as it describes voluntary actions without force, fraud, or coercion.
The victim, Jane Doe 102, began sexual activities with Epstein and Maxwell at age 15 and continued until 17 or 18, quitting her job at Mar-a-Lago to do so.
Epstein paid for an apartment for the victim near her family in West Palm Beach, which she considered independent.
The victim traveled to London and elsewhere for sexual experiences voluntarily, according to the letter's interpretation of her testimony.
The letter calls for a clarification of the legal definition of child sex trafficking for prosecutors and law enforcement.
